text: the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of this new Cara
Jackson record why does the Earth give
us people to love this is the debut
full-length LP of singer songwriter Cara
Jackson who's been low-key active for a
minute now for instance you can catch a
2019 EP that she dropped a while back if
you dig into her catalog but it seems
like a lot of her progression over the
years has been building up to the
release of this debut album and she must
have been doing something right in her
Pursuit Of Music so far on the Chicago
scene because on this record she's
aligned herself with such local talents
as kainas and Morimoto as well as nomdi
whose latest full-length LP is a
whirlwind of different genres and styles
and Cara comes together with her various
collaborators on this LP to make a
record that is colorful but yet
consistent built on intimate songs that
are gentle on the ears and yet intense
with passion and sometimes righteous
frustration the opening moments on the
cell LP are a somewhat awkwardly
performed little Lo-Fi piano ballad
which becomes a clever and funny
observation on the things people will do
for fame and attention it's an
interesting start to the lp that subtly
introduces us to the more theatrical
elements of the music that show up more
boldly later some strong sentiments are
expressed on the following no fun and
party as well which is not a favorite of
mine here for its three-part progression
which I think is very choppy there are
numerous other cuts on this record that
operate in what feels like chapters as
we move from section to section in the
song but none of them come across as as
fragmented as this one regardless though
Kara still comes through with some
hard-hitting bars on this cut lamenting
being taken for granted romantically and
told she's intimidating by past lovers
the songwriting gets even more blunt and
bold on the following [ __ ] Blues
where Cara describes what she
categorizes [ __ ] Behavior having her
time wasted being treated merely like an
emotional Refuge or like a romantic
vacation and in describing this scenario
she reveals how much of a Way With Word
she has with unique alliterations such
as coyotes and culottes clone for coffee
in open-toed shoes and evocative
metaphors such as when you're feeling as
broke as a bottle of booze like a soda
straw strangling you all of this playing
out over shifting tense dramatic chord
changes that feel like something out of
a musical theater production as there's
a lot of endearing camp on this project
especially on some of the dreamy outro
mantras of If I Had a Heart If I Had a
Heart and the assured realization that
she herself Kara is pretty top-notch or
just above the treatment that she's been
receiving romantically on the track we
also have a funny afterthought with this
track that comes in the form of therapy
a short musical extension where she
essentially describes uh men wanting her
to be kind of their therapist or a
motherly figure in a relationship
context the wit and sharp songwriting
continues on to the track pawn shop
whose open chords hand drums and Frank
vocal delivery remind me of the Laura
Marling song in the best way and Cara
kills it on the lyrics once again when
you become somebody's Bandit and their
heart becomes your loot what kind of
player does that make you and later you
pick me at a pawn shop I was used but
good as new shiny is a tattoo but
permanent as party balloons like already
on the first record Kara is showing
herself to have the potential to be a
poet of the highest order the
dramatically strummed guitar chords and
slow pacing on the cut brain makes it
feel almost like a campfire sing-along
which escalates into this dreamy display
of ethereal keys and some really soft
slide guitar too the vocals especially
shine on this one with carolining on all
of these elongated notes in her lower
range that come across very mesmerizing
as she sings about running away from the
kind of love that you deserve out of a
sense of fear the song free is an
interesting change of pace as it kind of
thrives off of this very slow gradual
build upward with the instrumentation
getting thicker and thicker till it
reaches this Crescendo of almost
blinding Beauty there's a noticeable
change to the general narratives of this
record on the song too with Kara kind of
freeing herself from the toxic romantic
situations that she may have described
previously now she is just free and not
wanting to be bothered or encumbered in
any way so just stay back the following
Lily is one of the simplest and sweetest
most direct ballads on the entire
project a really honest and heartfelt
expression of love and just a beautiful
Oasis in the middle of the record
because of that the touches of strings
and bouncing horns are great too it's
just an impeccable level of Elegance
being showcased on this one then we get
a very heavy and dramatic Trio of cuts
in the last leg of this thing there's
rat which if I'm not mistake taken kicks
off with like a Fievel Goes West
reference it's a moody narrative cut
with some lovely acoustic arpeggios
whose story I won't spoil and the
topical focus on the track is impressive
along with some of the noisy
instrumental embellishments calling away
in the background really adding to the
drama of the track then we have the
title track which is a profound and
heart-wrenching meditation on death
Kara's vocals are especially powerful
and backed up with these thick layers of
bass and vocal harmonies which just kind
of add to the song's overall urgency but
I love that musically compositionally
the whole thing kind of resolves and
warms up on a very positive Crescendo in
its final moments then the last full
structured song on the project is
curtains where Kara delivers a pretty
interesting self-assessment on whether
or not she is worthy of Fame attention
the Limelight is my life a curtain call
or a cane that yearns to yank me off am
I worthy of Applause which narratively I
think brings this thing things full
circle to the opening Sentiments of the
project on what people will do to
achieve fame and speaking of that
opening recognized track there is a
reprise of that song the second to last
cut on this record that comes to a very
Grim conclusion but with the song
curtains as the first verse establishes
itself the pianos the defined guitar
chords that come in have almost like a
Pink Floyd quality to them I would say
some Joni Mitchell Vibes begin to come
through as well and I love that the song
features a lot of bold changes across
its run time and yet still comes
together as a cohesive piece by the end
of it the short closing cut is a very
Stark acoustic cut with some kind of
tense and awkward lead vocals that
resemble that of the intro we're
bookending things here where kind of
finishing much in the same way that we
started but this track kind of ties the
records feelings on love up as opposed
to attention and fame and here we have
Kara kind of accepting the fact that
she's been kind of left in the Dust by
this person who kind of rejected her
wanted nothing to do with her and now
she's kind of shaking off the feelings
of neediness and want by uh kind of
laughing it off ignoring it and I guess
drinking a bit too and like the intro
cut after hearing so many very smooth
and uh confident fantastic vocal
performances across the record it's
clear she's giving us kind of an
amateurish Flair here with how she's
straining a bit vocally on this one but
yeah overall I think this is a great LP
the flow may be a bit fragmented yes but
the production poeticism performances
personality all stand out there's a lot
of good structure to these tracks a lot
of thematic Focus the record really has
it all outside of a few tracks paling in
comparison to others All Things
Considered I would say this is a great
and very impressive introduction to this
young and upcoming singer-songwriter I'm
feeling a strong eight to a light nine
on this one transition have you given
